bibl.title: Letter from James E. Peabody to Howard A. Kelly, November 26, 1928

div1.p: Peabody thanks Kelly for the photograph and hospitality in Baltimore. He discusses strategy for lobbying Congress in regards to the pension bill.

div1.head: Letter from James E. Peabody to Howard A. Kelly, November 26, 1928
div1.opener:
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
THE MORRIS SERVICE LEAGUE
James E. Peabody, Chairman Teachers Committee
TEL. KILPATRICK 8140
----
THE MORRIS HIGH SCHOOL
166th Street and Boston Road
NEW YORK CITY
{Done}
November 26, 1928.
Dear Dr. Kelly:
div1.p:
That superb picture has reached me, and you may be sure I am exceed-
ingly proud to display it. It is now at the American Museum, and the lan-
tern slide is promised in a few days. The original will be carefully pre-
served for my childrens' children. What a good time I had in your hospi-
table home.'. I cannot help envying you such a host of children and grand-
children. After reading that article in Scribners I can understand some-
what your surprising agility. But what an exciting life you have led. I
never had known before the half of your experiences.

It was kind indeed of you to promise the books for the recalcitrant
Congressmen. Here they are with their addresses as given in the World
Almanac: Hon. John ✓Q. Tilson (Majority Leader), New Haven, Conn. (He must
be well enough known there to receive the book, but perhaps it is safer to
send it to Washington; indeed Col. Wainwright tells me he is there already).
Hon. Harold ✓Knutson, Chairman of the Pension Committee, St. Cloud, Monn.;
Hon. Robert ✓G. Simmons, Scottsoluff, Nebraska. I wonder if you could also
spare a copy for Hon. J. Mayhew Wainwright, and for Senator Royal S. Cope-
land, both of New York, who are the authors of the bill. All these men
will probably be in Washington next week, and I am sure they too would be
proud to have an autographed copy. If you could send with each book a
statement of your deep interest in the proposed legislation, it would be
the best possible psychological introduction to the conference you Balti-
more Medical Leaders have promised to attend.

You were kind enough to give me Dr. Latimore's Boston address. I
took it down, but I cannot seem to find it. I wish much to see her, and deter
mine, if possible, the source of that “Gentlemen, I salute you” story. Mrs.
Reed told me in Washington she was sure it was authentic, in spite of Moran's
denial. Will you please ask Miss Davis to send me this address %Mrs. John
Brant, 141 Norwood Avenue, Newtonville, Mass. I shall be there until Satur-
day. I am sorry I did not see Miss Davis, for it was a great pleasure to
meet her. My little camera did a fairly good job, but I am sorry for the
scratches on the films. You may care to glance over the account of my trip.
I certainly had wonderful support in Washington and in Baltimore.
Please give my kind regards to your good people whom I met.

Hotel Belliven
Bukley &Newburg St.
Boston, Moro.
